title: Does the truth require your belief? - Quora

response.answer_text: Truth is infallibleand unchanging. Belief has the possibility of being wrong. I am at a game show. There are three doors. There is a brand new car behind one of the doors.( This last statement is true). I have to choose which door it is behind to receive the car. I wholeheartedly believe it is behind door number three.( this is belief). They open door number three and it is not there. Though the truth is the car is behind one of the doors, I had to rely on my own judgement to pick the door with the car. I didn’t know which door it was, so I had to choose. Belief gives way to doubt in this case, because I believed and was wrong. What if I choose wrong again next time? Now if I was told the car was behind door number two, I would know and not have to rely on my own judgement. So than the truth is there when I open the door and the car was there. I had to believe the information of truth was given. I didn’t have to rely on myself, but will recognize truth when it is revealed to be correct. Truth requires belief only to reveal itself to the believer, but not to truth itself. This is the issue many have with God. They want God to reveal itself before they believe it to be true. Truth need not prove itself, but the believer will see it as truth when they believe it. Truth will leave no room for doubt. If falseness is within any claimant of truth, then it is not truth. Truth never fails itself. So truth itself requires no belief, only the believer.

Does the truth require your belief? Yes and no. The truth is the truth and it does not require proof, does not need to follow logic, does not require peer review or testing to be true. It simply is. For you to know it as true, however, requires that it meet your bar requirement for proof of case. This can only be accomplished through personal experience or self delusion regarding a data point being assessed. Even in this case the data point is really only “possibly true” as personal experience is not totally reliable. Then there is the “nearly true” which are the nearly infinite number of “not truths” which appear indistinguishable from the actual truth due to similar yet not on the mark characteristics. These are more likely to be what you will think are true than actual truth if just by statistical probability due to sheer volume contrasted by the singular nature of the truth. Your belief, however, is required for you to build on data that is either “likely true” or “close enough to functionally use as true” the process of which may lead to higher truths despite faulty foundations. An example I use quite a lot is: if you have not tested the speed of light and you think that it is 186,000 m/s then you “believe” it is true. You do not “know” it is true. There is very very very little that any of is “know” is true beyond a shadow of a doubt despite that we are contained within the body of absolute truth which is existence. To take the data sets of others and the statistical analysis of people you never met does not prove anything except one’s willingness to trust blindly in others as being forthright and without conspiratorial agenda (which, while likely the case, should be enough to change “know” into “believe” for the self aware). To recap: no, it does not.

I would say no. Why? Well, belief is only the acceptance by the mind of an impression, a proposition, an idea, an as yet unevidenced claim that something either does or does not exist in a particular state. The word is full of truths, some of which we are familiar with. We call the latter group of things knowledge, which is familiarity with or awareness of the facts of a thing. Some truths are pleasant and others not. My mental impression of their existence, or even my complete ignorance of them, makes no difference to their existence. What exists, exists within the body of truth; that which is real and not merely imagined. The correct perception of something requires understanding, realisation, an appreciation of the thing or idea within a particular context. Truth is fact, not supposition, which is what belief is. While it’s common practice for belief to be conflated with knowledge or fact, this is a misleading notion. For example, consider the common saying, “I wish that I knew then what I know now”, most often said when one has realised that they made an error of judgement because of a past lack of information. It expresses regret about a past state, one that has since changed due to something realised or learned in the interim. A lightbulb moment has occurred. If belief and knowledge are to be considered synonymous, then we should or would be able to say something like, “I wish that I believed then what I believe now”. However, we never say this. Why not? If we think about it, it’s because we inherently realise that it was a past state of mind, driven by belief and ignorance, that gave rise to the deficiency that caused eventual regret upon realisation that knowledge was historically absent. That knowledge would have, or could possibly have, prevented the negative outcome or loss that resulted from our initial belief or mental impression. A clear thinker does not confuse belief with knowledge, or wisdom, though it may well allow us to backslide into the mire of subjective and self-seeking modes of thoughts where we deem it convenient to do so. Another example? Let’s propose that the moon exists. I also exist. Therefore, the moon exists because I exist. This assumes that the moon only exists on my sole account of awareness of it. Really? So, what happens when I am no longer conscious of the moon, say when I’m asleep? Does it cease to exist on my account? Surely not, but the lure of belief and egotistical thinking that it might do so, can be a comforting notion to think that we are somehow the centre of the Universe, rather than being a part of it. Belief grants power to unbridled imagination. All extreme ideas are based on belief of one sort or another. Beliefs are opposed to facts, and facts often come into conflict with reality, as they are egocentric and self-gratifying ideas. In brief, beliefs are notional and are merely conceptions about something, without reference to evidence, logic or knowledge. When you consider them closely, belief and knowledge are like oil and water. They may be mixed and shaken together for a time, but they eventually separate and become clearly distinct and visible. Beliefs, in the absence of a human mind to conjure them up, would cease to exist, while all that does exist and has ever existed would still continue manifest itself with reality.

Well, yes and no. That’s a complicated question. What does truth mean? Truth is not the same as objective facts — although people often conflate the two things. Truth can sometimes refer to objective facts. Facts never require our belief. It’s not a matter of belief that Paris is the capital city of France. It’s not a matter of belief that the sun rises in the East and sets in the West each day. Those are matters of facts, and when I speak them, I’m telling the truth in a certain kind of sense. But these facts remain facts whether or not I believe in them. And certainly my own beliefs can be out of line with the objective facts. If I told you the capital of city France was London, I can believe it with all my heart, but that doesn’t make it true. I’d still be wrong. But the word “Truth” can also refer to things other than objective facts. It can refer to philosophical or “human” truth — like the idea of The Golden Rule, also known as Reciprocal Altruism. So you could say that it’s a truth of human existence that most people would prefer to be treated with respect, have their needs and desires respected, and treated equally to others. We can codify that as some kind of spiritual stricture, or encode that in mythology and storytelling—both religious and secular. But it’s not exactly an objective fact — because not everybody follows this rule exactly, or even believes in it. These “human” truths are often somewhat subjective, or at least relative to our own values — which may or may not line up with the values of our own or other communities, or all other humans. Then there is also the idea of personal honesty — so a person can be telling the truth when they’re talking about anything to do with their own personal experience. Like, are they angry or sad or happy? Are they hungry or full, in pain, or feeling good? No one can tell them they’re not feeling those things — only they can say for sure, and they can tell the truth or they can choose to lie about it, and no one outside of themselves can really be certain about the difference. The same applies when they’re talking about their personal experience — about things that have been done to them, about things they’ve done, about goals and aspirations they may have, hopes, fears, etc. A person’s personal “truth” — including also their values, spirituality, and all of that — these are all impenetrable to others, except where we individually choose to share. This kind of truth sort of does require your belief — or rather doesn’t require it but is based on it. Because obviously your personal truth is based on what you believe is true for you and true about your life and experience, and no one can really judge that (not accurately) except you. And it’s the overlap between these two later forms of truth where morality really resides. To respect other people fully — i.e. to carry out the semi-universal truth that we all wish to be respected and treated fairly (i.e. the Golden Rule), it means we all have to respect the inner life (personal truth) of other people. And that doesn’t require “belief” so much as simply understanding the value of listening and respecting and being compassionate toward other people. That’s a moral truth that is about as close to an objective moral fact as morality ever gets. I certainly think it’s a truth that doesn’t exactly require our own belief to remain such a truth, but people certainly have to “believe in it” enough to act upon it. So given these three kinds of truth — the “truth” doesn’t require your belief to remain truth, but quite often your belief in the truth (your your beliefs about what the truth might be) are certainly going to determine how you act in the world, and that’s really what matters. It’s also important to remember the nature of belief in all of this. If we believe something, and then act upon that belief, it’s the nature of our human minds to focus mainly on the experiences that verify those beliefs to us. So, if you believe the world is coming to an end — whether by some kind of religious end times, or by climate change — that belief will effect your mindset. You’ll act in ways that reflect how you feel about this end of the world scenario. Your mind will focus on all the ways your belief is true, and that will reinforce your mindset — it’s a feedback loop. And so if you think the world is about to end, you may act in ways that actually make that prophecy come true. It’s the cliche of an alcoholic strugging to stay sober, but afraid they can’t — you fall off the wagon once and have a drink, and so you think you failed so bad that your’e already damned, so why not just keep drinking? I find so much of the dialogue around climate change, social injustice, poverty, etc. is like this — apocalyptic, and “fuck it” we might as well just move to thailand and get high and watch the world end. But then nobody so jaded and apathetic is going to be able to fix the problems that would prevent these crises.  Think about it in smaller terms — our fears often become self-fulfilling too. A socially anxious party thinks they’ll embarass themselves at a party. So they go to the party with this fear in mind, and then they start focusing on every little mistake they make, and before long they’re so wound-up and anxious that they can’t focus on the conversations they’re having with people, they’re sweating and nervous and making other people uncomfortable, and so they have a really awkward time, and really do end up embarassing themselves at the party, and leaving feeling like “I knew this would happen, why do I even try?” — But if they had let that fear go, or found ways to focus on other things, they’d have been calmer the whole time and the thing they were afraid of would not have happened — or if it had, it wouldn’t have felt so bad. It works the other way too — in mental health recovery, and even in sports and other success coaching, there’s the phrase “fake it till you make it” — which is verified by experimental psychology. If you act “as if” a certain belief is true, then you’ll begin to model the patterns and habits of behaviour that will make that belief a true reality in your life. It might feel weird at first, because it feels untrue, but eventually it works — and because you’re acting out this behaviour, it actually works backwards and serves to re-write your beliefs about yourself of the situation. So your “fake” action becomes your truth, if you work at it. And so, if you have social anxiety because deep down you think you’re a worthless loser, then suspending that idea and still putting yourself in social situations and acting as if people respect you and you feel you have value yourself, then you’ll begin to develop confidence, and actually manifest circumstances where people do treat you with respect, and where you feel respected and worthwhile — and genuinely confident. So it works. We even know that if you smile when you feel awful, it will help you feel a bit better. And this is true if you make yourself smile with your muscles — but it’s also true that simply holding a pencil in your teeth, which forces your mouth into a shape similar to a smile — has the same effect. So belief, action, and “truth” are all connected. It’s just a question of what you’re trying to accomplish, and where you want to get in life. What does the truth, or your own truth, perhaps, serve? And how do your beliefs and actions other align or not align with that?
